person.note:
Constant Troyon (August 28, 1810 – February 21, 1865) was a French painter of the Barbizon school.
Watercolor on paper landscape painted by Troyon.
Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot (July 16, 1796 - February 22, 1875) was a French landscape and portrait painter as well as a printmaker in etching.
John Edward Parsons was a lawyer in New York City. He was president of the New York City Bar Association from 1900 to 1901.

Florence Van Corltandt (née Field) Bishop was the widow of David Wolfe Bishop when she married John E. Parsons. Florence was the daughter of Benjamin Hazard Field, a merchant philanthropist, and the mother of David Wolfe Bishop Jr. and Cortlandt F. Bishop, the pioneer aviator.

Harriet Valentine "Hattie" Crocker was the daughter of a railroad magnate and wife to a wealthy financier and attorney, Charles Beatty Alexander. Mrs. Alexander was a leading figure in San Francisco society and then New York City. She was the epitome of America’s 19th-century social elite, holding philanthropic events and lavish parties.

Abbas II was the last Khedive of Egypt, and his rule ended around the time that the Ottoman Empire joined WWI. His strong nationalistic attitude led to several conflicts with Britain, who were occupying Egypt at the time. The Khedive strongly disliked the British, supporting nationalistic groups within Egypt until he was abdicated from his position.
No further information.
Gertrude Walrond was the daughter of Sir John Walrond, 1st Baronet, a politican for the British Conservative Party. She married Sir Thomas Acland on november 1st, 1879.
Sir Charles Thomas Dyke Acland, 12th Baronet graduated from Eton college and Christ Church, Oxford. On November 1st, 1879, he married Lady Acland (Gertrude Walrond).
Lady Agnes Mary Feilding was the daughter of Rudolph William Basil Feilding, 8th Earl of Denbigh, and Lady Denbigh. In 1892, she married Charles Edmund de Trafford with whom she had three children.

Ay was the king of ancient Egypt and had a short reign from 1323 to 1319 BCE. Before his reign, he worked up the ranks of the civil service and the military. Then, he took on the role of elder statesman for King Tutankhamen, whom he later succeeded. His military functions included master of the horse and troop leader, but his primary title, “God’s Father,” indicated a close relationship to the royal family.

Eighteenth Dynasty pharaoh who ruled 1351–1334 BC, husband of Nefertiti. Changed state religion from polytheisim to monothesim, worshipping the sun disk: the Aten. Established a new capital (Akhetaten) in modern Amarna. What was probably his mummy was discovered by Theodore Davis and Edward Ayrton in 1907 in tomb KV55.

Edith Cecilia Alderson, known as "Eda," was born in 1867. She was the daughter of the Reverend Frederick Alderson and Katherine Guest, who was a daughter of John Josiah Guest, a wealthy Welsh businessman. She spent considerable time travelling abroad with her mother's sister, Enid Layard. She never married and died in a nursing home in Salisbury in 1956.
Daughter of Charles B. and Harriet Alexander.
Daughter of Charles B. and Harriet Alexander.
Daughter of Charles B. and Harriet Alexander.

Charles Beatty Alexander was a wealthy financier and attorney in New York, New York. For many years he was a Regent of the University of the State of New York, responsible for the general supervision of all educational activities within New York State. He was husband to Hattie Crocker, a prominent socialite.

Harriet Valentine "Hattie" Crocker was the daughter of a railroad magnate and wife to a wealthy financier and attorney, Charles Beatty Alexander. Mrs. Alexander was a leading figure in San Francisco society and then New York City. She was the epitome of America’s 19th-century social elite, holding philanthropic events and lavish parties.
Married to Henry Addison Alexander, nee Green. Mother of Eleanor Butler Alexander (1888–1960) who married Theodore Roosevelt III (1887-1944).

Vere Speke Alston was born in 1853 in England. He graduated from Cambridge in 1876 and began practing law soon thereafter. He became a judge at the Court of Appeals of the Mixed Courts in Cairo, where he met his wife, an American socialite, in the 1890s. He divided his time between Egypt and other European properties and died in France in 1931.

Anne Sophia Penn Chew was born into the wealthy Chew family, who had been a landowning family in the United States since the seventeenth century. She married Vere Alston, a judge in the courts set up after the British occupation of Egypt, in 1898, and they resided in Egypt for most of the rest of their lives. She died in France in 1931.

Amenhotep II was an Egyptian pharaoh who ruled during the New Kingdom period c. 1426-1400 B.C.E. The son of the warrior king, Thutmose III, Amenhotep placed great emphasis on conquest. He was buried in Thebes in the Valley of the Kings along with other notable pharaohs like Tutankhamun.
No further information.
Miss Alda B. Atchison was a missionary and teacher stationed in Cairo at the American Mission College for Girls during the early 1900s. She worked closely with Miss Carrie M. Buchanan.

Hugh Auchincloss was a financier who married Emma Brewster Jennings, the daughter of an original founder of Standard Oil. He was educated at Yale and worked in the firm of Auchincloss Brothers of New York. He also managed private companies in mining, manufacturing, and transportation, while also having leadership positions in other organizations based in New York City. He owned 'Hammersmith Farm' in Newport, RI.
Emma Brewster Jennings was the daughter of Oliver Burr Jennings, a stockholder of Standard Oil. She married Hugh Auchincloss on Nov. 19, 1891 and was known mostly for her philanthropy work.

Edward Russell Ayrton was the son of William Scrope A., a British consular in China. After graduating from St. Paul's School, he became an assistant to Sir William Flinders Petrie and eventually joined the Egypt Exploration Fund in 1902. He also worked with Edouard Naville and H. R. Hall at the Deir el-Bahri and with Theodore Davis in the Valley of the Kings.
Ruby White Colburn was the wife of Doctor William Wilberforce Baldwin, a renowned physician in Rome.

Lilias Margaret Frances, or Countess Bathurst, was a British newspaper publisher who owned The Morning Post. It was passed onto her by her father, and she was the only female owner of a major newspaper in the world. The newspaper held a far-right stance, so it played an important role in the Conservative Party.

John Baird was a British politician, serving as the governor-general of Australia from 1925 to 1930. He attended Eton College and graduated from Christ Church, Oxford, entering the British diplomatic service in 1894. After serving as governor-general, he moved back to Britain, becoming the chairman of the Conservative Party from 1931 to 1936.
Laura L. Tifft married Dr. Seth R. Beckwith on October 11, 1853. She was the mother of Louise Tifft Beckwith (Mrs. Brown).

Eugene Benson was an American painter and art critic. He was born in Hyde Park in 1838 and by his early twenties was studying painting at the National Academy of Art. He was elected a member of the academy in 1862 and worked alongside such painters as Winslow Homer and Eastman Johnson. He fell in love with the married Henriette Malan Fletcher and they moved to Venice together in the 1870s to escape social censure, where they lived until their respective deaths.
Bernard Berenson was an American art historian, critic, and collector specializing in the Renaissance.
Mathilde de Lagarde Boal was the wife of Theodore "Terry" Boal. In 1895, they had a son named Pierre, and eventually moved back to the United States in 1904.

Theodore Davis "Terry" Boal was an army veteran and architect. After graduating with a degree in architecture from Iowa State University (1889), he joined an architectural firm in Colorado. However, in 1894, he traveled to Paris, France to continue his studies and met Mathilde Lagarde. They married and had a child named Pierre. They eventually moved back to the US where he became a senior partner at the Boal and Harnois architecutral firm in Colorado.

Sir Edgar Bonham-Carter was the fifth son of Henry Bonham Carter. Sir Edgar held a long and esteemed legal career, taking roles like that of a British barrister, jurist, and legal administrator. He also held a 5 year term of office as judicial adviser in the semi military, semi-national administration set up in Mesopotamia, where he reestablished the judicial system of Sudan and Iraq. He was also a member of the Royal Society for Asian Affairs in London that stood to advance public knowledge of Asia. He was also the first Chairman of the Executive Committee of the British School of Archaeology located in Iraq.
Born Alice Whetten, she married Isaac Bronson, member of a prominent banking family, in 1866. After she was widowed, she and her daughter Ethel spent most of their time in Rome.

Louise Tifft Beckwith was the wife of Walter Brown. She was the founder of a co-operative linen and toy factory in Venice, Italy and created numerous lace works which are currently displayed at the Cleveland Museum of Art.

Walter Francis Brown was an artist known for his paintings of Venetian scenery. After recieving his BA from Brown University, he moved to Paris, and later Venice, to continue his studies. He married Louise T. Beckwith in 1885.
No further information.

Carrie was the daughter of Rev. James N. and Rosanah S. (Alexander) Buchanan. After graduating from Western Seminary in Oxford, Ohio in 1892, she moved to Luxor, Egypt where she co-founded and became the principal of the American Missions Girls’ School. After becoming ill during her time in Egypt, she moved to California where she died two years later.
No further information.
No further information.
Amelie Burgnoyne was a maid for Emma B. Andrews. While she was originally born in France, she immigrated to the US in 1876.

Mary Lyman Morgan was a member of the prominent Morgan family of American bankers. She married Walter Hayes Burns, a partner at her father's bank J. S. Morgan & Co, in 1867. They purchased a large estate near London in 1884 and lived there for the remainder of their lives.

Harry Burton was born in Lincolnshire, England in 1879 to a family of 11 children. Italian Renaissance scholar, Robert Cust became his benefactor, providing Burton with an education, training and an apprenticeship. He became a talented photographer of Florentine paintings. While in Italy, Burton met Theodore Davis who hired him to photograph and later direct Davis' excavations in the Valley of the Kings until 1914 when Davis stopped work. Burton was then employed by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York as a photographer for the museum's "Egyptian Expedition." Burton worked for the Met until his death in 1940. Harry Burton captured more than 7,500 excavation photographs in and around the Valley of the Kings throughout his career working in Egypt during the early 20th century. His photographs of sites such as Thebes, Deir el-Bahri, and Wadi Natrun brought him great regard as one of the foremost archaeological photographers of his time. He is most famous for his documentation of Howard Carter’s discovery of the tomb of Pharaoh Tutankhamen, 1922-1933. Most of his work was done between 1911-1936. Burton appears frequently in the Emma B. Andrews diaries, since she was in close contact with him from 1903-1913.

Jeanette Ridgeway Buttles was an artist and author who travelled Egypt alongside her aunt Emma B. Andrews. She wrote a book titled The Queens of Egypt, which included several pictures of artifacts and monuments discovered by Howard Carter.

John Lambert Cadwalader was a lawyer and the 10th U.S. Assistant Secretary of State. After graduating from Princeton University with his MA in 1859, he recieved his LLB from Harvard University. He was a trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a board member of the New York Zoological Society among many others.

Revered Colin Campbell attended the University of Glasgow where he received his MA, BD, and DD. He was a minister in St. Mary's church from 1878 to 1882 and spent most of his later life travelling to and collecting works in Egypt. After his death, his collection was donated to the Hunterian Museum, Royal Museum of Scotland, and Dundee Museum.

Dr. Clarence Gordon Campbell attended Wabash College (1883-1886) and received his M.D. from Bellevue Hospital Medical Center. He spent some time in England and Germany to continue his studies and eventually became an attending physician at the New York Hospital from 1892-1898. After spending the following decade traveling extensively, he became the President of the American Eugenics Research Association and wrote multiple books on various medical practices as well as his religious beliefs.

Helen Fahnestock Hubbard was a philanthropist involved in many cultural projects and charitable works both in New York and France. After graduating from the Comstock School in New York, she moved to Paris where she funded numerous musical programs, and eventually moved back to New York to open the Manhattan School of Music. She married Dr. Campbell in 1896 – with whom she traveled to Egypt – and had a daughter named Helen. In 1928, she remarried with John Hubbard.
The Earl was an artist and patron with a devotion mainly to landscapes. Egypt was one of his many travel destinations sought out both for art and the improvement of his health.

Almina Herbert, Countess of Carnarvon, was the wife of George Herbert, Lord Carnarvon. She was the illegitimate child of the wealthy banker Alfred de Rothschild who provided her with a considerable trust. With her biological father’s financial support, she helped fund the search and excavation of Tutankhamun’s tomb.

George Herbert, fifth earl of Carnarvon, was a British excavator and collector. He is best known for aiding Howard Carter with the opening of King Tutankhamun’s Tomb in 1922, although he did not live to see its clearance completed. Beyond the realm of excavations, Herbert also curated an expansive collection of Egyptian antiquities throughout his life.

Egyptologist, artist and archaeologist, Carter is most famous for his discovery of the tomb of Tutankhanun in 1922 while working for Lord Carnarvon. Prior to this, he was employed as one of Theodore Davis's archaeologists.

A well acclaimed musician descended from a notable family. His stay in Egypt was the result of his largely unsettled lifestyle. While he and his wife visited Egypt they both performed for Emma B. Andrews and accompanied her to artistic productions.
19th century impressionist painter, travelled to Egypt in 1910.

Sir Ernest Cassel was a prosperous merchant banker who was said to have a natural affinity for business. He invested well and was able to spread his ventures into countries like Egypt, Ameria, and France.

Jean-François Champollion, sometimes known as the "Father" of Egyptology, was a French philologist and founding figure in the field. He was born in France on December 23, 1790 and developed an early interest in oriental languages. He studied the Rosetta Stone starting while at university in Paris and eventually published "Lettre à M. Dacier," the foundational translation of Egyptian hieroglyphics based on the stone, in 1822. Later in life he became the Curator of Egyptian Antiquities for the Louvre and made an expedition to collect artifacts there on behalf of the museum in 1828-29. He died of a stroke in Paris in 1832 at the age of 41.
Margaret Walrond was the daughter of Sir John Walrond, 1st Dt. On Mar. 30, 1875, she married Lord Clinton. Has a son named Robert Trefussis.

Lord Clinton attended Eton College and Christ Church, Oxford Univeristy where he recieved his BA and MA. He was the Conservative MP for North Devon (1857-1866) and went on to become the Chairman of the Devon County Council (1889-1901). He married Margaret Walrond (Lady Clinton) on Mar. 30, 1875 and had seven children. His death was mentioned in Vol. 11 March 30, 1904.
No further information.
No further information.

Princess Louise Margaret of Prussia, later the Duchess of Connaught and Strathearn, was a member of the House of Hohenzollern and of the British royal family. She spent the first twenty years of her marriage accompanying her husband on his various deployments throughout the British Empire, and she served as the viceregal consort of Canada when her husband served as the governor general.

Prince Arthur William Patrick Albert was the seventh child and third son of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert. He took on the title of the Duke of Connaught and Strathearn. He married Princess Louise Margaret of Prussia, who then became Duchess of Connaught and Strathearn. He served in the British Army where he became the Governor General of Canada starting in 1911 and until 1916.

Princess Patricia of Connaught was a granddaughter of Queen Victoria, and she grew up as a member of the Royal Family. In 1918 she was named Colonel-in-Chief of Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry, and she personally designed the badge and colours. She later relinquished her royal title by marrying naval Admiral Alexander Ramsay in 1919.

Lady in waiting to the Queen of Italy. Weigall wrote in a letter to his wife Hortense: 'She is such a delightful woman in spite of powder and a little paint I fear. She is lady in waiting to the Queen of Italy and tells the most amusing stories of Italian court life.'

Jean-Baptiste Camille Corot was a french landscape painter who inspired the impressionist movement in the 19th century. Before he was allowed to puruse his career in art, he was apprenticed to a draper. Although he regularly exhibited his art in the Paris Salon, he failed to sell many paintings. However, by 1846 he was made a member of the Legion of Honour and was promoted to be officer in 1867.

Lancelot Crane is best known for his artistic renderings and illustrations of art that covered Egyptian tombs, like the the tomb of Haremhab. He worked with Theodore Davis on many tombs and his artwork is prominently displayed at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City. He trained at the Royal College of Art.

Edmund Joseph Curley emigrated from Ireland to the USA about 1845. After the Civil War, Curley established the whiskey distillery E. J. Curley & Co. near Lexington, Kentucky. Between 1907 and 1912, Curley (using the honorific "Major") spent the summer months in Newport, Rhode Island where he entertained members of Newport society and likely made the acquaintance of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore M. Davis and EBA. In late 1912, he (and others including his friend the American banker Edward Tuck and his wife) visited EBA in Egypt (see diary entry for Saturday. Dec. 21, 1912).

Charles Trick Currelly attended the Harbord Collegiate Institute and received his BA and MA from the University of Toronto. After completing his amsters, he became interested in archaeology and worked under the Egyptologist, Flinders Petrie at the Egypt Exploration Fund. He went on to become the founding director of the Royal Ontario Museum where he worked until his retirement.

Robert Henry Hobart Cust was an art historian. He attended the Eton School (1879-1882), and recieved his BA at the Trinity College Cambridge (1883-4) and MA at the Magdalen College Oxford (1886-7). He was a member of the Burlington Fine Arts Club and has published books on artists such as Botticelli (1906), Leonardo da Vinci (1907), and Benvenuto Cellini (1912).

The Villa De Albertis (located in Quarto dei Mille, Genoa, Italy) was often used as a place by former British Prime Minister Lloyd George and other delegates to convene during the Genoa Conference of 1922.

The Villa De Albertis (located in Quarto dei Mille, Genoa, Italy) was often used as a place by former British Prime Minister Lloyd George and other delegates to convene during the Genoa Conference of 1922.
Maximilian D. P. Dalison was a member of the Egypt Excavation Fund where he worked with archaeologists such as Naville and Weigall at Deir el Habri and tomb KV57 of Horemheb.

Georges Emile Jules Daress was a French egyptologist who was employed by the Egyptian Museum in Cairo in 1887. He has published numerous works in relation to his excavations in the Valley of the Kings, Medinet Habu, and Luxor, to name a few.

A successful American lawyer, Davis began sponsoring excavations in the Valley of the Kings under the Egyptian Antiquities Service in 1902. His sponsorship led to some of the most important archaeological discoveries in Egyptology (e.g. KV45, tomb of Queen TIye; KV47, tomb of Horemheb; KV55, the Amarna cache; and KV54, Tutankhamen's embalming cache).

Count Luis de Cuadra was a Spanish Nobleman who converted from Catholicism to Islam due to his sexual orientation. He was inspired to convert to Islam by the poetry of Persian astronomer and mathematician Omar Khayyam, who wrote openly of homosexual relationships. In Cairo, Luis de Cuadra met Louis Massignon (1883-1962), with whom he had an intimate relationship with. Louis Massignon would later become a well-known Catholic scholar and an influential figure in Catholic-Muslim relations. Luis de Caudra died by suicide in a Spanish prison in 1921.

person.persName: de Trafford, Lady Agnes Mary Pia Fielding

person.note: James Teackle Dennis attended Lafayette College in Easton, Pennsylvania where he became a lawyer, following in his father's footsteps. After marrying Miss Ida Lee Wade in 1893, they traveled to Europe which led him to study Egyptology at Johns Hopkins University. During his time there, he decided to pursue a career in Egyptian studies and eventually joined the Egypt Exploration Fund in 1905. Much of his and his wife's work at the Deir el Bahri site can be seen in the Dennis Collection of Egyptian Antiquities exhibited at the Malden Museum.

Miss Ida Lee Wade married James Teackle Dennis in 1893. During her time in Egypt, she worked with her husband and other Egyptologists such as Dr. Edouard Naville as a photographer, artist, and decipherer.

Louisa Frederica Augusta Cavendish, the Duchess of Devonshire, was a German-born British aristocrat. She was the former wife of 7th Duke of Manchester and later the first wife of 8th Duke of Devonshire. These marriages led to the nickname "Double Duchess". She was the Mistress of the Robes to Queen Victoria and also hosted the Devonshire House Ball of 1897.

Spencer Compton Cavendish, 8th duke of Devonshire was a British statesman with a long career in politics. His opposition to his own Liberal Party led him to be the leader of the Liberal Unionist Party, where he became increasingly identified with the Conservatives. On three occasions he declined the office of prime minister, and he held Devonshire's fourth longest ministerial career in modern British politics. He was the second husband to Louisa Augusta, the Duchess of Devonshire.
Michael Zeno Diemer was a German painter who was well-known for his panoramic battle scenes and marine paintings. He attended the Academy of Fine Arts, Munich.

James Dixon was an English Egyptologist. He worked for the Egypt Exploration Fund in 1909-1911 as a draughtsman and copyist, reproducing inscriptions and other objects that were discovered. In 1912 He joined the Wellcome Sudan Expedition near Sennar as excavator and draughtsman. He also served as the Second-Lieutenant in the 6th Battalion of the Border Regiment until he died in the line of duty in 1915.
No further information.

person.persName: Donatello di Niccolò di Betto Bardi

person.note: No further information.
No further information.

George Perry Duprey was born in London in 1875. He earned an L.D.S. from the Royal College of Surgeons in England in 1901 and afterward set up practice in Cairo for many years, at least between 1910 and 1925. By 1930 he had returned to the UK and continued to practice dentistry there.
No further information.

Amelia Ann Blanford Edwards spent most of her life as a writer, publishing numerous novels and writing for various newspapers. However, after visiting Egypt in 1873, she gave up her work as a novelist and became an advocate for the exploration and preservation of ancient Egyptian monuments. In 1882, she founded the Egypt Exploration Fund as well as the Department of Egyptology at the University College London in 1885.
EPB married August E. Fraass Company Inc. (New York City) salesman Werner D. Mueller (1892–1964) [later Dr. Werner D. Mueller] on 06 September 1921 in Brattleboro, Windham, VT

David Charles Erskine attended the Harrow School in London and went onto pursure higher education in France and Germany. In 1897, he became the secretary to the Governor-general of Canada and eventually became Liberal MP for West Perthshire (1906-1910). He was also known for his involvement with the British economic, John Maynard Keynes.
The sister and likely traveling companion of Grace Henop as well as the wife of Talbot Ewart, 5th Baronett of Glenmachan.

Gaspard Farrer was one of three sons of Sir William Farrer. His family has long ties to Farrer & Co., a law firm. He was a Managing Director at Barings bank between 1902-1925. He was discovered to be the founder of the National Fund (a British charity dedicated to paying off England's national debt), giving an anonymous donation of 500,000 pounds in 1928.

Hon. Francis Henry Everard Joseph Feilding graduated from Trinity College, Cambridge University where he received his B.A. and LL.B. He was a practicing barrister and served time in the military during WWI as well. In 1919, he married Stanislawa Janina Tomczyk. He is the son of Lord Rudolph Feilding of Denbigh and the brother of Lady Agnes.

Hon. Francis Henry Everard Joseph Feilding graduated from Trinity College, Cambridge University where he received his B.A. and LL.B. He was a practicing barrister and served time in the military during WWI as well. In 1919, he married Stanislawa Janina Tomczyk.
Worker at the Grande Bretagne Hotel in Florence.

George Willoughby Fraser was a civil engineer who worked for the Egypt Exploration Fund. He began working in Egypt in 1889, and worked closely with Percy Newberry over many years, drawing maps and plans. He had an extensive personal collection of Egyptian scarab artifacts. Fraser died in 1923.

Dorothy Julia Spencer was born in India in 1877. She was the daughter of a minor officer in the British Army. She grew up in London and married George Willoughby Fraser in 1902. Her husband worked in Egypt at the time, and she spent much of the next several years there. She died in Bath in 1923.
Elizabeth Fowler Gallaudet was a teacher traveling with (and most likely employed by) the Mrs. and Mr. Walter Jennings. She was good friends with Mrs. Auchincloss (Emma B. Jennings).

Hedwig von Rosen was the daughter of a Jewish man (her father worked for the king of Hungary) and a Swedish woman. She was married to Alan Gardiner, who would become a preeminent figure in the field of Egyptology and assist in the opening of Tutankhamun's tomb, in Vienna in 1901. She would later be described by her daughter Margaret as "quick, spontaneous, vivid and illogical," and had a bright personality.
Matilda Travers married Walter Gay in 1889. She was the daughter of William Travers, a Wall Street investor and co-founder of the Saratoga Race Course.

Walter Gay was an American painter most well-known for his still lifes and interior scenes. In 1876, he moved to France with his wife where he studied under the French painter Leon Bonnat. Gay recieved numerous awards in the US and in France including a gold medal in the Paris Salon (1885), Associate Academician in the National Academy of Design (1904), and Commander of the Legion of Honor (1927).
Worker at the Grand Bretagne Hotel in Florence.
Miss Jeannette Gordon was a teacher for the American Mission School in Luxor, and worked along side other missionaries such as Miss Carrie Buchanan and Miss Alda Atchison.
A prominent member of the British Diplomat corps and a Consul General in Egypt from 1907-1911.

The daughter of Charles Rudd, a financial 'magnate' and former business partner of Cecil Rhodes in South Africa. She is also known as the wife of Sir John Eldon Gorst, often referred to as 'Jack.' Lady Gorst accompanied Jack on many of his business trips to Egypt.
The daughter of Sir Jon Eldon Gorst, a prominent member of the British Diplomat corps and a Consul General in Egypt from 1907 to 1911. Miss Gorst accompanied her father on many of his trips to Egypt.

person.persName: Gosford, Lady Louisa Acheson, Countess of
person.note: Louisa Acheson, also known as Lady Gosford, served as a Lady of the Bedchamber to Queen Alexandra. During the First World War she was president of the Central Workrooms of the British Red Cross Society, and was appointed Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire. She was also the wife of the 4th Earl of Gosford.

person.persName: Gosford, Lord Archibald Acheson, Earl of
person.note: Archibald Brabazon Sparrow Acheson also known as the 4th Earl of Gosford or Lord Archibald Acheson was entitled to an automatic seat in the House of Lords after his father's death. He was Lord Lieutenant of Armagh from 1883 to 1920, and served as Vice-Chamberlain of the Household of Queen Alexandra. He was also the husband of Lady Gosford.
Sir Henry John Lowndes Graham was a Knight, and Clerk of Parliaments.‏

Married Capt. Walter Alexander Trefusis, in June 1911. Daughter of Sir John Graham, and niece to the Lord of Northhampton. Trefusis divorced her in 1918 accusing her of adultery with John Craigie, who she married in 1919.
No further information.

Lady Theodosia Louisa Augusta Acheson Cadogan was the daughter of Archibald Brabazon Sparrow Acheson, 4th Earl of Gosford and Lady Louisa Augusta Beatrice Montagu. She was married to Sir Alexander George Montagu Cadogan, a British civil servant.

Sir Thomas Henry Hall Caine attended the Hope Street British Schools in Liverpool and served an apprenticeship in hopes of becoming an architect. However, after moving back to the Isle of Man, he became interested in pursuing a career as a writer and published his first work, Sonnets of Three Centuries, in 1882. In 1886, he married Mary Alice Chandler, with whom he spent most of his time in the following decades traveling to various countries, including Egypt, where he wrote his most controversial work, The White Prophet (1909).
No further information.
No further information.
Hathor was an Egyptian goddess who represented a variety of things such as love, beauty, and fertility. She was the daughter of Ra and wife of Horus. She was also known as the protector of women.

Grace Hennop was the wife of archaeologist Robb de Peyster Tytus, whose work took the couple around the world. These two factors appear to have led to their aquaintance with Emma B. Andrews and Theodore B. Davis. The couple had a house in Tyringham, Mass close by a farm owned by Emma.

Horemheb was the last pharoah of the 18th Dynasty of Egypt. He was commander of the army under Tutankhamun, and is believed to have been born as a commoner. His tomb was discovered in 1908 by Theodore Davis, though his sarcophogus was empty and his remains have never been found.
No further information.

Lewis Morris Iddings was an American diplomat. He was born in 1850 and initially worked as a journalist before getting the position of secretary at the embassy in Rome, working there between 1897 and 1905. Between 1905 and 1910 he served as Consul General at the embassy in Cairo before returning to the embassy in Rome, where he worked until his death from heart failure in 1921.

Louise Belden was born in 1849 in San Jose, California. She was the daughter of Josiah Belden, an early California resident, politican and businessman. She married Lewis Iddings, a journalist and later diplomat, in 1885. They moved to Europe where Lewis worked in the diplomatic service in Rome for most of his life, excepting the period between 1905-10 where they worked for the consulate in Cairo. Louise died in Italy in 1943.

A famous Dutch Egyptologist and antiquities dealer who is best known for his link to the "Insinger papyrus, "one of the oldest writings about Egyptian wisdom that is now on display in the National Museum of Antiquities in Leiden.

Winifred Ives was the daughter of Brayton Ives, the President of the Northern Pacific Railway. She was close friends with Grace Green Alexander and her daughter Eleanor Roosevelt (wife of Theodore Roosevelt Jr.).

Annie Burr Jennings was the daughter of Oliver Burr Jennings, the director of Standard Oil. She established many community institutions in Fairfield including the Fairfield Historical Society and the Fairfield Public Library. Due to her philanthropic work, she was given the title, "First Lady of Fairfield."
Jean Pollock Brown Jennings was the wife of Walter Jennings with whom she had three children.

Walter Jennings was the son of the businessman, Oliver Burr Jennings. After graduating Yale University in 1880, he became the Director of Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the President of Jekyll Island Club. He married Jean Pollock Brown in 1891 and had three children.

John de Monins Johnson was a British papyrologist. He was educated at Magdalen College School and Exeter College. He served in the Egyptian Civil Service from 1905 to 1907 and excavated for the Graeco-Roman branch of the Egyptian Exploration Fund at Atfih in 1911. He joined the Oxford University Press in 1915 and was appointed Printer to the University in 1925.

Cyril Jones was the brother of the excavator, Ernest Harold Jones. He was a student at the Queen Elizabeth Grammar School between 1905 and 1909 and joined Harold on his return to Egypt. Due to Harold's worsening condition of tuberculosis, Cyril served as an assistant to Harold in his work in excavation, supervising, and letter writing. Later in Cyril's life, he became a farmer in South Africa.

Daniel Jones worked for Theodore Davis for more than twenty years after coming to the US in 1885. He spoke Arabic and was wellversed with hotel employees, merchanets, and dragomen. In 1913, he committed suicide at the Davis residence in Newport.

Ernest Harold Jones was an artist and excavator most known for his vibrant watercolor paintings of antiquities. He worked at sites in Upper Egypt and the Valley and the Kings, and most notably worked with Lord Carnarvon, Theodore M. Davis, and Professor J. Garstang.

Michel Casira was an antiquities dealer in Cairo who owned a shop near the Shepheard’s Hotel. He was active from 1898 until his death in 1911. He worked with other dealers such as Maurice Nahman who he was involved with in the sale of the head of Queen Tiye from Gurob in 1905.

Dikran Kelekian was a notable art collector and dealer with ties to many well-known individuals and artists such as Henry Walters, John D. Rockefeller Jr., Mary Cassatt, Pablo Picasso, and Henri Matisse. He studied ancient Near Eastern history at Robert College in Constantinople and went on to open numerous shops in cities such as New York, Paris, and London, exhibiting his collections in museums all over the world as well. In addition to his work as a dealer, he was appointed the Persian Council in New York and as the Commissioner for the Persian Pavilion at the World’s Columbia Exposition.
Wife of Dikran Kelekian.
Robert Talbot Kelly lived in Egypt for many years, pursuing his artistry professionally. He encountered Emma B. Andrews and company during their travels and had tea together.

Herbert Kitchener was appointed governor general of eastern Sudan in 1886, and later became commander-in-chief of the Egyptian army in 1892. Kitchener was second-in-command of British forces during the Boer War, and became known for his use of civilian prisoner camps, for which the term 'concentration camp' comes from. Kitchener was the secretary of state for war during World War I, and died when his ship was sunk by a German mine in 1916.

Eleanor Salome Wilson married Norwegian noble and diplomat Niels Joachim Knagenhjelm (1861-1907) in 1895 with whom she had 3 children including Nils Theodore, Harold Jacob, and Carl Nathaniel. She was the sister of Alice Wilson (1869-1952) and a niece of Theodore M. Davis.
Dionysios Kytikas was a well-known antiquities dealer in Cairo, Egypt, along with his relative Panayotis Kytikas. He also published numerous works on Arab literature, Egyptology, and Pharaonic Egypt.

Pierre Lacau was a French Egyptologist and philosophist. He had a long career in Egyptology inspired by Maspero. He began his work for the Cairo general catalouge in 1899, where he continued to write until the first World War. From 1914 to 1936 he served as Egypt's director of antiquities and oversaw the 1922 discovery of the tomb of Tutankhamun in the Valley of the Kings by Howard Carter.

Barbour Lathrop was an American millionaire known for using his inherited wealth to travel the world. He is perhaps best known for his partnership with American botanist David Fairchild (1854-1964), who is credited with introducing many exotic crops to American farmers, such as the avocado.

Lady Enid Layard was wife to her older cousin Austen Henry Layard, an archaeologist and diplomat. Her family and marriage status allowed her opportunities of travel and luxury. Per Henry’s will, her collection of early Italian art, portraits, and jewerly are now displayed in the British Museum and the National Gallery in London.

Corinna Lindon Smith was an activist and scholar, primarily studying Arabic and Islam. In 1899, she married Joseph Lindon Smith with whom she worked with on numerous excavation sites in Egypt. She also advocated for many causes such as health programs and Native American rights, and supported organizations that promoted studying Middle Eastern history.

Joseph Lindon Smith was an American painter who was known for his depictions of Egyptian tombs. While travelling in Egypt, Smith's work captured the attention of the archeologists at Giza, who tasked him with documenting paintings found in the excavation. His art became well reputed, and they are seen as some of the best documentations of newly exposed antiquities. Later in his life, Smith became the president of the American Reach Center in Egypt, alongside his wife Corinna who was a member of the board.

Ernest Longfellow was an American artist known for his paintings of landscapes and human figures from around the world. He travelled to Egpyt to create some of his work, in addition to Europe and East Asia.

Victor Loret was a French Egyptologist who studied under Gaston Maspero at the École des Hautes Études and Coll. de France. He went to Cairo with Maspero as an original member of the French Institute of Arch., and he worked in the Valley of the King. During his time as the head of the Egyptian Antiquities Service in 1897-9 he discovered KV35, the tomb of Amenhotep II. He later founded a school of Egyptology in Lyons, becoming one of the most successful teachers in France.

Albert Morton Lythgoe was most known for his role as the first curator of Egyptian Art at the Metropolitan Museum. After receiving his masters from Harvard in 1897, he was employed at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and lectured at Harvard as well. After resigning from both positions in 1906, he began working at the Metropolitan Museum, working with other egyptologists such as Howard Carter and Herbert Winlock. He also assisted in numerous excavations such as the Tomb of Tutankhamun.

Gaston Maspero was an Egyptologist who taught Egyptian language at the College de France. After arcaheological work in Egypt he was appointed by the Egyptian government in 1881 as Director General of Antiquities, which was during Theodore Davis's period of excavation in the Valley of the Kings. He also co-founded the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, with its vast collection of Egyptian artifacts, in 1902. His works include Les Momies royales de Deir-el-Bahari 1889 (The Royal Mummies of Dayr al-Baḥrī”), L’Archéologie égyptienne 1887 (“Egyptian Archaeology”), Causeries d’Égypte 1907 (New Light on Ancient Egypt), and Les Contes populaires de l’Égypte ancienne 1914 (“Popular Tales of Ancient Egypt”).
Louise Balluet married Gaston Maspero in 1880 with whom she had 3 children. She is also the sister of Paul d'Estournel de Constant, winner of the 1909 Nobel Peace Prize.

Sir John Grenfell Maxwell was a prominent officer and general in the British Army. He served in the Egyptian War of 1882 as well as World War I and was awarded with various promotions and honorary titles throughout his career. An amateur egyptologist, he enjoyed collecting and was friends with Lord Carnarvon and Howard Carter.
No further information.
Sir Robert Malcolm McIlwraith was an English lawyer and judicial advisor to the Egyptian government. He published a variety of works in legal journals, most notably works on Egyptian law.

Ramesses-Mentuherkhepeshef was the son of the 20th Dynasty pharaoh Ramesses IX, who ruled between 1129 and 1111 BCE. He was his father's intended heir, but predeceased him. He is buried in the Valley of the Kings.
Employed by Theodore Davis as a connection to dealers and persons of importance.
Mohammed Mohassib was a popular Egyptian antiquities dealer in Luxor, and most of his collections were known for being incredibly valuable.

Jane Graham Frost was born to the American Brigadier General Daniel Marsh Frost. She grew up in St Louis, Missouri, and married the baronet Lewis William Molesworth in 1875. Her husband was first High Sheriff of Cornwall and later an M.P. She died of a wasp's sting to her jugular vein while at home in Cornwall in 1913.

J.P. Morgan was born into a family of bankers which influenced his own decision to enter the financial world. The financial empire he built was so successful and powerful that even the United States government turned to him for advice in times of trouble. His power and status did not come without criticism though, as he was accused of creating business monopolies and unfair advantages. Besides his business dealings, he was also an avid art collector and donated many pieces to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

Dr. Ferdinand Gordon Morrill, M.D., was born in Boston in 1843. He graduated from Harvard in 1869 and afterward established a successful medical practice in Boston, as well as working for the Children's Hospital there. He married his wife Arria Niles in 1871. For the last part of his life he and his wife would winter in Egypt, and he died in Aswan in 1907.
Gouverneur Morris was a great grandson of the Founding Father Gouverneur Morris. After graduating from Yale University, he published numerous novels, some of which were eventually adapted into films.

Amelia Sophronia Canfield was born in Ohio in 1853. She was the daughter of Allen Canfield, a farmer. She married the Rev. Chauncey Murch in 1880 and they moved to Egypt as part of the American Presbyterian Mission shortly thereafter, where they lived until the reverend's death in 1907. Afterwards she and her son James moved back to the United States. She died in Indiana in 1916.

Maurice Nahman was recognized as one of the most important antiquity dealers in Egypt at the time, operating in Downton Cairo throughout much of the late 1800s and early 1900s. While he was most known for his dealings in Egyptian artifacts, he was also a collector of Coptic and Islamic objects as well.

Marguerite Naville married Edouard Naville in 1873. She accompanied him on a total of 14 trips to Egypt (1884-1914) where she managed excavation sites, cared for the workers, and recorded much of the findings made by Edouard and other Egyptologists at the time. A number of her photographs and drawings can be seen in her husband's publications.
Doris Newberry was the first born child of Mary Newberry and Wolcott E. Newberry. She travelled around Europe with her mother and Theodore Davis.

Ellen Mary B. Newberry was the daughter of Levi Buttles, Emma B. Andrews' cousin. Theodore Davis adopted her when he noticed Levi Buttles' limited resources. Especially close with Andrews, she travelled around Europe and Egypt, eventually marrying Wolcott E. Newberry, a mining engineer.

Percy Newberry was an egyptologist and archaeologist who worked with the Marquis of Northampton, Theodore Davis, and Robb de Payster Tytus in the Theban Necropolis. His first solo excavations were at Beni-Hasan and El Bersha with Petrie. Later on he served as a profesor at the University of Liverpool, Kings College, and Cairo University. Davis and Emma Andrews offered financial support for his Theban excavations in the early 1900s, and Emma supported his catalog of scarabs.

Henry Roderick Newman was an American artist. He was the son of a doctor, born in 1843 in upstate New York state, and grew up in New York City. He initially studied medicine like his father, but after his father's death in 1861 decided to pursue art full time. He was strongly influenced by the Pre-Raphaelite movement, and eventually became a close friend of the hugely influential Victorian critic John Ruskin, who encouraged his art. Newman was 'monkish,' and would retreat into himself for several days while working on his paintings. He was also delicate, and eventually began spending winters in Egypt for his health, passing the rest of the year in Italy. He painted numerous watercolors of the scenery he saw there. He died in 1917.
Erskine E. Nicol was a landscape artist and the son of the renowned Scottish painter Erskine Nicol. His works, like his father's, were often exhibited at the Royal Academy of Arts in London.

Cecilia Marion Elizabeth Frere was born in 1879 in London. She was a member of the Frere family, who were prominent abolitionists in the nineteenth century. Her father Douglas died young of tuberculosis and she and her four sisters were raised by their mother in London. She met her husband, the painter Erskine Nicol Jr., in Egypt, where they bonded over a mutual fondness for art. They married in 1911. Their daughter Mary (b. 1913) would marry Louis Leakey and go on to become a pioneering figure in the field of paleoanthropology.

William George Spencer Scott Compton also known as the 5th Marquess of Northampton was educated at Trinity College. He served in the Diplomatic Service as Second Secretary to the British embassies and travelled in Egypt. After becoming interested in Egyptian excavation he financed the excavations in the Theban necropolis directed by Newberry and Wilhelm Spiegelberg.

Louise was a daughter of King Edward VII of the UK and a granddaughter of Queen Victoria. She was born in 1867 and married the Scottish peer Alexander Duff, Earl of Fife, in 1889; he was later made a duke by her grandmother. They had two daughters. In late 1911, she and her husband were shipwrecked off of the coast of Morocco while sailing to Egypt, and her husband later died in Aswan as a result of the accident. She lived in Scotland for the rest of her life and died in London in 1931.
Alexander Duff, 1st Duke of Fife, was married to Louise Victoria, the daughter of King Edward VII. After being shipwrecked on a trip to Egypt, he fell ill and died in Aswan.

Henry Fairfield Osborn was a famous American scientist and professor. He made significant academic contributions to Columbia University by establishing a biology department. As president of the New York Zoological Society as well as the American Museum of Natural History, he made great strides in popularizing the field of animal morphology.
MP Almeric Paget attended the Harrow School and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge. In 1893, he established the Dominion Coal Company Ltd. and was appointed High Sheriff of Suffolk in 1909.

Sir Arthur Henry Fitzroy Paget served as the Commander-in-Chief, Ireland from 1912-1914 where he took part in the Curragh Incident. In 1918, he was given the title of King of Arms of the Order of the British Empire which he held until his death in 1928.

Mary "Minnie" Fiske Stevens was the daugter of Marietta Reed and Paran Stevens, the New York hotelier. Afer moving to Europe in 1872, she eventually married Sir Arthur Paget (1878) with whom she had 4 children.

Yacoub Artin Pasha was educated in Instanbul and Europe before becoming the tutor for Ismail Pasha's children. He held numerous government positions including the Khedive's Secretary of European Affairs, undersecretary for the Ministry of Public Education, and the representative of Egypt on the Suez Canal Company Board.

Fakhri Pasha, also known as Fahreddin Pasha, was a Turkish career officer as the commander of the Ottoman Army and the governor of Medina from 1916 to 1919. He was nicknamed "The Lion/Tiger of the Desert" and is most known for defending MEdina in the Siege of medina during WWI.
Isma'il Pasha was the Kehdive of Egypt and Sudan from 1863 to 1879 when he was removed from power by British forces.

Reverend Endicott Peabody attended Trinity College, Cambridge and returned to the US in 1880 to train as a minister, graduating from the Episcopal Theological School in 1884. Later in his life, he founded the Groton School for Boys and Brooks School.
No further information.
No further information.

Hilda Urlin Petrie was the wife of Sir Flinders Petrie. She studied geology and was employed by Petrie as an artist, marrying him soon after. The two left for Egypt in 1896 and she became the chief maanger at many of the excavations her husband worked at. She published numerous works both by herself and with Petrie. The two had a son and daughter.

Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie was an English Egyptologist and first chair in Egyptology in England at the University College London. He surveyed many archaeological remains in England, Egypt, and Palestine, and published numerous works on his findings. Despite the lack of a formal education, he made many major archaeological discoveries and was eventually knighted for his services in 1923.

Chilton Latham Powell was an American professor of English and an author. His grandmother, Sarah Phelps Hardy, was one of Emma B. Andrew's sisters. After receiving his education at Amherst College and Columbia University, he was a professor at Johns Hopkins University and Amherst College during his career.

Anne Abernethie Pirie Quibell was a Scottish excavator and draughtsman. She went to Egypt as an assistant to Petrie and helped him on a number of his excavations, contributing to several of his volumes. She later assisted her husband, James Quibell, in his archaeological work. She published two popular books—Egyptian History and Art and A Wayfarer in Egypt

Pandeli Ralli was a British politician. His father was a member of Ralli Brothers Ltd., an extremely successful Greek merchant business. He was a member of Lord Kitchener's inner circle, and was a member of the Liberal and Liberal Unionist parties in England during his lifetime.

Williams attended Lake Erie College (B.A.) and Chicago University (Ph.D.). After receiving her Ph.D. in Egyptology, she became the first female professionally-trained Egyptologist in the US. She worked as the assistant curator in the Metropolitan Museum and served with the Chicago Expedition in Egypt from 1926-7. She also wrote for the Journal of Egyptian Archaeology and published numerous studies regarding Egyptian antiquities as well.

Coming from a long line of Rathbones, Elena Rathbone was the daughter of William Gair Rathbone VII and Blanche Luling. She was a supporter of District Nursing, and she served several positions until becoming vice-president in 1956 for the Queen's Institute for District Nursing. She married Bruce Richmond in 1913.

Son to William Rathbone VI and Lucretia Rathbone, married to Blanche Rathbone (nee Luling) and father to Elena Rathbone, William Gair Rathbone VII worked within his family business, the Rathbone Brothers. Continuing his father's legacy, he also served as Honorary Secretary of the Queen Victoria's Jubilee Institute for Nurses.
Blanche Luling married William Gair Rathbone VII, and was mother to Elena Rathbone.

person.xml:id: Ream_Robert_Clarke - possibly tagged in vol. 13 as #Ream

person.note: George Rodier was an artist and professor of philosphy at the Sorbonne.

Theodore Roosevelt Jr. was the son of President Theodore Roosevelt, and he served in WWII as a brigadier general. He was also a politician, becoming the Governor of the Philippines and Puerto Rico as well as the Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

Prince Giambattista Rospigliosi was a member of the Rospigliosi family. The Rospigliosis were minor nobles in Italy dating from the thirteenth century, rising as far as to have a member become pope (Clement IX, pope from 1667-69 CE). Giambattista moved to New York after his marriage to the American socialite Ethel Bronson in 1903 and thereafter divided his time between the upper crust of New York and Rome.
Geraldine "Geanie" Rutter was the sister of Arthur Weigall. She travelled frequently with her brother and in 1904, she married Jack Rutter, giving birth to her daughter Betty in July of 1908.
S-ankh-aten, known as Ankhesenamun, was the Great Royal Wife of pharaoh Tutankhamun. There is no record of what happened to her after she died, which is why she is called Egypt's lost princess.
Breifly mentioned, attended lunch with Emma B. Andrews
Fariida was a missionary and former student of the American Mission School in Luxor, headed by Miss Carrie Buchanan. She married Samuel Ali Hiseen (Mr. Sammary) in April of 1906.

Samuel Hiseen was a key figure in the Sudan Pioneer Mission (SPM), founded in 1900. After receiving his education from a missionary training college in England, he traveled around Europe for a few years before returning to Nubia for a fellowship with the American Mission School. He joined SPM as an evangelist and missionary, and deemed it his life mission to spread Christianity throughout Nubia.

Fleming Mant Sandwith was born in 1853. He earned a medical degree from St Thomas's hospital in 1876 and began serving in the British military immediately following. In 1883 he moved to Egypt to treat a cholera epidemic there and set up medical practice as well as writing books such as "Egypt as a Winter Resort" on the climate and travel practices there for a wealthy audience. He moved back to London around the turn of the century, where he served as a lecturer and authority on tropical medicine. He died in 1918.

Reverend Archibald Sayce was a professor of Assyriology at Queen's College in Oxford. His work, which involved the writing of scholarly reviews and articles on Near Eastern civilizations, took him to locations all over the world in addition to Egypt.
No further information.

Seti II was the fifth Pharaoh of the 19th Dynasty, and he one of the last rulers of this era. During his rule, he was known to have faced his rival Amenmesse, who had gained control of Thebes and Nubia.

Siptah was a pharaoh of the Nineteenth Dynasty who ruled between 1197 and 1191 BCE. He took the throne at the age of ten or eleven with the assistance of a powerful official named Bey; his parentage is uncertain. He died at around the age of sixteen, possibly of polio, and is buried in the Valley of the Kings.

Wife of Joseph Lindon Smith, academic with a focus on Classical Arabic and Islamic Theology, prominent figure in the American Research Center in Egypt, and activist for numerous struggles. She was born in 1876, married in 1879, and died in 1965.
A vacationer with his school friend Robert Ream.

George Somers Clarke was originally an architect, primarily designing and restoring churches. After retiring from general practice in 1902, he moved to Egypt where he became an archaeologist and oversaw the restoration of various temples and published numerous architectural descriptions of important excavations at the time.
Husband of Mrs. Henry Taft and brother of President William H. Taft. Known for his work as an lawyer and special assistant to the attorney general in anti-trust prosecution.

Julia Walbridge Smith Taft married Henry W. Taft on March 28th, 1883, with whom she had four children. She was active in many Catholic charities at St. Patrick’s Cathedral including Helpers of the Holy Souls, the Little Sisters of the Assumption, and the Catholic Center for the Blind.
Professor Tarbell's reasons for being in Egypt are not yet known. However, he spent several days with Emma B. Andrews, dining with them after delivering a letter.
Entombed in KV 14 before being moved to KV 13. Cartouches were found elsewhere and their discovery was noted in volume 15. The last ruler of the New Kingdom, succeeding her husband Seti II.

Known for expanding the borders and influence of the Egyptian New Kingdom to their gratest extent. He is referenced within the diaries with relation to architecture which is admired by Emma B. Andrews - The Karnak Temple Complex in particular is noted.

Thut-ankh-Amon, commonly known as Tutankhamun, was an Egyptian pharaoh during the 18th Dynasty of the New Kingdom of Egypt. After his father tried to change the ancient Egyptian religion into monotheism, Tutankhamun began his reign by restoring it back to polytheism, which was a monumental achievement after years of religious turmoil. The discovery of his tomb was one of the biggest archeological finds in history as it contained several artifacts that revealed information about royal life in ancient Egypt, making Tutankhamun one of the world's most famous pharaohs.
Sister of Captain Trefusis, stayed one night with Andrews and Davis who found her to be good company. She married Colonel Harry Stuart Ravenhill on Feb. 22, 1911 and had one child.

Robert Trefusis was the son of Charles Trefusis, 20th Lord Clinton and Margaret Walrond (Lady Clinton). In 1915, he married Lady Dorothy Marguerite Elizabeth Herbert. He is the brother of Capt. Walter Trefusis and Evelyn Trefusis.

Captain Walter Trefusis was the son of Charles Trefusis, 20th Lord Clinton and Margaret Walrond (Lady Clinton). In 1911, he married Marjorie Winifred Graham, but they divorced in 1917. He was the brother of Robert Trefusis and Evelyn Trefusis.

Constant Troyon was a French painter of the Barbizon school. Although he spent most of his life as a landscapist, he became internationally recognized for his animal paintings, which are now held in numerous museums such as the Louvre and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Archer Robert Upton was the manager of the Guildford Hardy Plant Nursery in Guildford, England, which specialized in "alpine plants" that thrive in rocky soil.

Friedrich Wilhelm Freiherr von Bissing was a German egyptologist and Professor of Egyptology at the University of Munich. For a time, he worked for Gaston Maspero, producing volumes for the Cairo Catalogue.
Elisabeth Margarete Karoline Von Carlowitz was the wife of the Baron von Bissing, whom she married in 1904.
Major General James Kiero Watson. Father of Lt. Colonel James Kiero Watson who served in the British and Egyptian armies after studying at Sandhurst. Came to tea with Emma B. Andrews.

Lina Post Webster was the wife of Hamilton Fish Webster. After moving to Newport with her husband, she became very involved in the community, becoming the first woman to be elected to the Representative Council in Newport (1933) and serving as the president of the Newport County Women's Democratic Club (1934).

Arthur Weigall became an Egyptologist after studying the subject for several years before working under Flinders Petrie and Friedrich Wilhelm von Bissing. At 25, he assumed the position as Inspector of Antiquities for Upper Egypt and wrote several books and biographies about the tombs that he helped recover. Weigall eventually became a set-designer in London as well as a journalist for Daily Mail, where he covered the opening of Tutankhamun's tomb.
The first wife of Arthur Weigall.

Mary Cabot Wheelright was an American anthropologist best known for her work in the American Southwest regarding the Navajo. She was born into a wealthy Boston family whose wealth she inherited. She established the Wheelright Museum of the American Indian which remains a popular tourist attraction in Santa Fe, New Mexico.
Sister to Robert Cust, Wherry was a nurse, and author or works of biography, art and folklore.
Daughter of Albinia Wherry, niece of Robert Cust.

Thomas Whittemore is best known for founding the Byzantine Institute in 1930 and initiating the conservation project at Hagia Sophia in Istanbul, Turkey in 1931. He also worked with Edouard Naville as the American representative for the British-run Egypt Exploration Society. With a history in academia, he also held titles as a docent, assistant professor and was a special collaborator of the U.S. Bureau of Education.
She first arrived in Egypt in 1895 as part of a Nile cruise during which she fell in love with her soon to be husband, Almeric Paget. She is noted to have later wintered in Egypt frequently.

Hugh Whitaker was a close colleague of Percy Newberry and assisted him on numerous excavations including the discovery of the tombs in Akhmim. He was also close friends with Lady Layard who wrote about him frequently in her journals.
Charles Whymper was a British painter and engraver who was popular for book illustrations on hunting and travelling.

Dr. Augusta Williams was a physician who served as chief surgeon at Vincent Memorial Hospital in Boston. She was also a member of many municipal activites in the Boston area throughout her career, including heavy involvement in the local school board. Dr. Williams served in France during World War One and worked with the American Red Cross in the war's aftermath.

Alice Wilson was the daughter of Nathaniel Wilson, a prominent Washington DC-based lawyer. She was born in DC in 1869. She spent a lot of time travelling abroad, including passing multiple winters in Egypt with Theodore Davis and Emma Andrews. She never married and died in 1952 at the age of 83.

Herbert Eustis Winlock was an American egyptologist for the MET. After he graduated from Harvard, he became involved in various expeditions with the MET including the discovery of the tomb of Tutankhamun by Howard Carter. He has also published numerous works, his most well-known being Tutankhamun's Funeral (1941).
